title: 108_hr2221
content: The Act titled "Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act" ensures availability of contact lens prescriptions to patients. The "Fairness to Contact Lens Consumers Act" mandates that prescribers must provide patients with a copy of their contact lens prescription upon completion of a fitting. Prescribers are also required to provide or verify the prescription electronically if requested. Additionally, prescribers are prohibited from tying the purchase of contact lenses to the provision of a prescription or charging extra fees for it. Patients cannot be compelled to sign waivers or releases for their prescription. Patients cannot be compelled to sign waivers or releases for their prescription. Contact lens prescriptions expire based on state laws, typically lasting one year from the issue date. However, they can also expire earlier if specified by the prescriber based on the patient's ocular health. Advertisements and representations must adhere to specific content guidelines. The Act prohibits advertising contact lenses without a prescription and prohibits prescribers from waiving liability for eye examination accuracy. Violations will be treated as FTC Act violations, and a study and report are required. The Federal Trade Commission will conduct a study on competition in the sale of prescription contact lenses, examining state laws on verification, prescriber compliance, enforcement, impact on competition, and verification standards by retail sellers. The Federal Trade Commission will study the impact of state laws on verification, prescriber compliance, and competition in the sale of prescription contact lenses. This includes examining the effect of laws on ocular health, compliance by sellers, brand name prescriptions, and any other issues affecting competition. The Commission will consult the FDA on these matters and submit a report within 9 months of the Act's enactment. The Chairman of the Federal Trade Commission will submit a report to Congress on the study required by the Act. SEC. 8. DEFINITIONS. The term "contact lens fitting" in this Act refers to the process that starts after the initial eye examination and ends when the prescriber is satisfied with the fit. It may include determining lens specifications, evaluating the fit of the lens, and follow-up examinations. The term "prescriber" refers to an ophthalmologist, optometrist, or other authorized person under State law to issue contact lens prescriptions. A contact lens prescription is issued by a prescriber, such as an ophthalmologist or optometrist, in accordance with State and Federal law. It includes the patient's name, examination date, issue and expiration dates, suitability for contact lenses, and necessary parameters for manufacturing and duplication. The contact lens prescription includes the prescriber's contact information, expiration date, and necessary details for lens manufacture. The Act will become effective 60 days after its enactment.
